_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Basic Organic Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
Genencor International Wisconsin, Inc.
Risk Management Plan


Introduction to Facility & Regulated Substance

Genencor International Wisconsin, Inc. (?GCOR?) is an industrial biotechnology facility located in Beloit?s Industrial Park.  This ISO-9000:2000-certified-facility employs approximately 96 people and operates under a team-based organizational structure.  Genencor International, Inc. assumed ownership of the facility in February 2002 from Enzyme Bio-Systems, Ltd.  In 2002, efforts were initiated to implement an Environmental Health & Safety Management System for the site, guided by sustainable development principles.  This effort continues.

The facility manufactures enzymes through a fermentation-based process. Enzymes are chemicals comprised of large proteins, and have been used in the food and detergent manufacturing industries for many years.  The site?s manufactured enzymes are primarily intended for use in the grain processing industry.   The facility operates a continuous 24-hour-per-day process and has on-site Maintenance and Laboratory support.  Staff support includes site Management, Environmental Health & Safety, Engineering, Purchasing, Finance, and Systems personnel.

Anhydrous ammonia is the regulated substance under EPA Risk Management criteria and is used in the enzyme manufacturing process.  The covered process for the site?s Risk Management efforts includes the anhydrous ammonia storage/delivery system and on-site chillers.  The process is divided into the following sections or ?nodes? for the purpose of this program:
?    Ammonia truck unloading
?    Ammonia storage tank
?    Ammonia tank discharge piping
?    Process piping
?    Chillers:  compressor
?    Chillers:  condenser
?    Chillers:  expansion valve
?    Chillers:  evaporator


Chemical Safety

GCOR?s overall approach to chemical safety is comprehensive.  Systems are engineered with safety and environmental aspects in mind, with input from affected areas of the plant prior to constructio

n or use.  The goal is to provide a safe workplace while minimizing any environmental impacts.  Release prevention methods are implemented where possible, including computer controls, automation, containment of outdoor tanks; inside sump areas; and neutralization capabilities.

Site commitment to environmental health & safety includes the following examples:
The Environmental Health & Safety budget is established to provide:
?    Appropriate and adequate personal protective equipment
?    Appropriate post-offer and annual medical examinations
?    Training
?    Air monitoring equipment and analysis
?    Hazardous waste pick-up for a small quantity hazardous waste generator
?    Emergency Response Team equipment and supplies

A Safety Committee is in place to ensure that plant safety is continually reinforced.  
The role of this support team includes the following:
?    Help identify, prioritize and address physical hazards through plant walk-arounds
?    Help define ?minimum safe work practices?
?    Help communicate impacts to employees
?    Help others to act
Member responsibilities include:
?    Represent their functional areas as members of the Safety Committee
?    Facilitate safety program implementation
?    Help to establish minimum safe work practices
?    Participate in safety walk-arounds
?    Communicate back to their functional teams

The GCOR corporate sustainability vision and expectations lend guidance to site efforts.
Genencor International Sustainability Policy:
?Using our expertise in modern biotechnology, Genencor seeks to become a leader in sustainability. We will strive to emulate nature?s elegance ? respecting the interrelationships of living organisms and making the most of the resources we use.  Through innovation and collaboration we will protect the environment, promote the well being of our employees and the world community.  

In the spirit of this intent, we will organize our work activities to improve continually in reducing the impact we have on the environment and to promote ef

ficiency and fairness in our activities.  We will meet legal and internal requirements, minimize pollution and preserve resources.  These efforts will be widely communicated to employees as part of core corporate values.  Progress will be monitored and communicated to our stakeholders, and we will use their input to improve our performance as corporate citizens.?  



New employees attend approximately 7 hours of initial safety training, which includes chemical awareness training as well as various OSHA and EPA required information.  Job-duty training is ongoing for each employee and occurs with co-worker trainers utilizing training manuals and SOP?s.  Genencor believes in being proactive in its training endeavors and strives to encourage employees to attend specific training associated with their job duties that go above and beyond the basic job requirements.  

Capital projects deemed necessary for environmental, health & safety reasons are implemented and supported through the capital expenditure process.


Emergency Response 

The site Emergency Action Plan addresses how employees shall respond to emergencies, including hazardous weather; fire; building evacuation; hazardous device threat; and hazardous material spills.  All employees are trained in the site Emergency Action Plan as part of the established initial safety training for new employees.

An Emergency Response Team (?ERT?) has also been established at the site.  ERT training includes Industrial Incipient Level Fire Brigade; Technical Level Industrial Chemical Spill Response; First Aid/Adult CPR; Automatic External Defibrillator; and Bloodborne Pathogens.  

ERT activities include yearly training as well as drills to prepare for incident handling.  On-site ERT equipment is maintained to support the ERT efforts and includes SCBA?s, Level B chemical resistant suits, and chemical absorbent materials.  

The site Emergency Response Plan for a Hazardous Substance Release is in place to provide ERT guidance

for spill operations.  The Incident Command System is the designated management system for emergencies and is included in the plan.  The plan outlines the responsibility of involved personnel during an incident; discusses the Incident Command System; gives instruction for securing outside emergency assistance; addresses internal and external notifications including the media/public; outlines emergency procedures for general emergency response; addresses spill control, personal protective equipment & first aid; and covers disposal & decontamination.  All ERT members are trained in the site Emergency Response Plan for a Hazardous Substance Release.  


General Prevention Measures

Genencor has a number of measures in place for spill prevention.  These include, but are not limited to, preventative maintenance work; standard operating procedures which are updated at least bi-annually; employee training; back-up equipment where possible; and computer-monitored level indicators with interlocking systems when process limits are reached.  The facility has 24-hour team-based process coverage in the facility, including a full-service maintenance department.  The facility also operates under ISO 9000:2000 certification which ensures among other things, that procedures are updated and used for plant operations in addition to proper handling of all documents.

The presence of an Emergency Response Team (as outlined earlier) is intended to ensure that all incidents are addressed as soon as possible to prevent an escalation of the incident if possible.


Five-Year Accident History

There have been no accidents at GCOR?s Beloit facility involving the anhydrous ammonia system that resulted in any on-site or off-site effects.


Changes to Improve Safety

A Process Hazard Analysis was conducted for the site?s anhydrous ammonia system in April 2004.  This was led by an experienced outside consultant and completed by a team with members representing the site?s anhydrous ammonia & chille

r suppliers, Maintenance, Engineering, and Environmental Health & Safety.  Twenty-four recommendations for improvement were generated from the Process Hazard Analysis.  Twelve recommended action items are complete and have been implemented; the remaining action items are scheduled for completion during the next year.
